title: The New York Times - Breaking News, US News, World News and Videos
description: Live news, investigations, opinion, photos and video by the journalists of The New York Times from more than 150 countries around the world. Subscribe for coverage of U.S. and international news, politics, business, technology, science, health, arts, sports and more.
keywords: news, live updates, latest news, breaking news, local news, current events, top stories, livestream, live video, world news, us news

p: Judge Holds Trump in Contempt Over Gag Order and Warns of Potential Jail Time
As testimony resumed, the judge overseeing the criminal trial fined Donald Trump $9,000 for violating a gag order by amplifying attacks on witnesses.
Trump, Venting About Lawyer in His Criminal Trial, Seeks More Aggression
Todd Blanche upended his career to represent Donald Trump and has been his favorite lawyer. But Mr. Trump has made him a focus of his episodic wrath.
Election updates: In a lengthy interview, Donald Trump left open the possibility of violence after the election.
The judge in Donald Trump’s hush-money trial said he could attend his son’s graduation in Florida next month.
College Students and Police Clash on Campuses Across U.S.
Pro-Palestinian demonstrators took over a Columbia building, and the campus was closed to most students. Elsewhere, more student protesters were arrested.
The police arrested 25 protesters at a university in Northern California, ending the occupation of a building.
Hamilton Hall at Columbia University has a long history of student takeovers.
Black Entrepreneurs, Frustrated by High Rates, Look to the Election
In the battleground state of Georgia, some Black business owners are frustrated over the impact of higher interest rates, a source of economic anxiety.
Europe’s Economic Laggards Have Become Its Leaders
More than a decade after painful austerity, Greece, Portugal and Spain are growing faster than traditional powerhouses like Germany.
High Federal Reserve interest rates are not crushing growth. A look at wealthy people helps explain why.
8 Officers Are Shot, 4 Fatally, While Serving Warrant in Charlotte, N.C.
Four officers, three of them members of a U.S. Marshals task force, were killed on what was the deadliest day for law enforcement in recent years.
Here’s what to know about the police shooting in Charlotte.
‘Hell’s Kitchen’ and ‘Stereophonic’ Tie for Most Tony Nominations
The Alicia Keys semi-autobiographical musical and David Adjmi’s behind-the-music play each picked up 13 nominations.
Broadway opened 12 shows in nine days to make the Tonys deadline. Here’s what that looked like.
Hear Alicia Keys on how she reimagined her 2001 hit, “Fallin,’” for Broadway.
U.N. Court Rejects Request to Halt German Arms Sales to Israel
The request, brought before the court by Nicaragua, had potentially wide implications on whether countries supplying arms are liable for how they are used.
Honeybees Invaded My House, and No One Would Help
Thirty states have passed laws to protect the pollinators. But when they invaded a Times reporter’s house, she learned that the honeybees didn’t need saving.
Even as He Faces Prison Time, Binance’s Founder Plans a Comeback
Since pleading guilty to violating money-laundering rules, Changpeng Zhao, who ran the crypto giant, has networked across the U.S. to set up his next act.
Inside an Abortion Clinic Days Before Florida’s Six-Week Ban Takes Effect
On one of the last days it would be legal to get an abortion under the state’s current 15-week ban, a clinic in Fort Pierce was completely booked.
By the time a woman is considered six weeks pregnant, she would have had two weeks, at most, to realize it.
Aboard a Navy Submarine Navigating the Arctic
A Times photojournalist embarked on a nuclear-powered attack sub to see how the Pentagon was training for a potential war below the frozen sea.
Even Outside the Courtroom, Trump’s Bombast Is Less Effective
That Strange Piece of Metal Origami Embodies All Elon Musk’s Flaws
The Exit Interviews: 12 Departing Lawmakers Tell Us What Congress Is Really Like
The Price We Pay for Having Upper-Class Legislators
Saying Goodbye to My Brilliant Friend, the Poetry Critic Helen Vendler
The Three Shows I’m Pulling for in the Tony Awards
Cows Are Just an Environmental Disaster
Trump Is Flirting With Quack Economics
I Was an Attorney at the D.A.’s Office. This Is What the Trump Case Is Really About.
This Isn’t the China I Remember
Some Concrete Reasons Not to Be Totally Panicked
Class of 2024, It’s Not in Your Head: The Job Market Is Tough
For Trump, a Long Day and a Long Week Ahead
When It Comes to TikTok, the World’s Democracies Have Played the Sucker for Far Too Long
I Was a Graduate Student at Columbia During the Protests of ’68
Here’s why more Latino voters find Donald Trump appealing.
150 People Sue, Saying They Were Abused as Minors in N.Y.C. Custody
The plaintiffs say they faced sexual and other physical abuse at juvenile detention centers and on Rikers Island.
In Reversal, Expert Panel Recommends Breast Cancer Screening at 40
Some researchers said the advice did not go far enough. The panel also declined to recommend extra scans for women with dense breast tissue.
Child Killed in London Sword Attack, Police Say
A 14-year-old boy was killed and several people were hospitalized in a stabbing spree in northeast London, the police said. A 36-year-old man was arrested.
The Lakers Are Out of the N.B.A. Playoffs. Now Come the Questions.
Los Angeles’s unflattering finish leaves the head coach’s future in serious peril, and LeBron James’s options open.
Jazz Saved the Bassist Luke Stewart. Now He’s Working to Rescue Others.
Stewart’s many projects — Silt Trio, Irreversible Entanglements, Blacks’ Myths and others — make strong statements and foster community. A new LP is out Friday.
